items.title: Interstellar comet nears Earth as NASA reports major 2025 discoveries

featured_image.name: An interstellar comet is passing by Earth tonight—here’s how to see it

items.description:
As an interstellar comet makes its closest approach to Earth today, NASA and international astronomers cap off 2025 with a year of discoveries that may reshape our understanding of the cosmos—from potential first glimpses of dark matter to evidence of the universe's earliest stars.

Comet 3I/ATLAS, the third confirmed interstellar visitor to our solar system, will pass within 270 million kilometers of Earth on December 19[1][2][3]. NASA coordinated observations using the James Webb Space Telescope, Hubble, and the Mars Perseverance rover to study the ancient wanderer, which may be older than our solar system itself[4][5]. The comet's unusually high carbon dioxide content and age offer scientists a rare window into the chemistry of distant star systems[6][5].

items.title: Antarctic ice melt could disrupt ocean currents vital to global climate

featured_image.name: A hidden Antarctic shift unleashed the carbon that warmed ...

items.description:
A delicate balance between melting ice shelves and sea ice production in Antarctica controls one of Earth's most crucial ocean currents, and climate change could tip the scales with potentially dire consequences for global weather patterns, according to new research published today.

Australian scientists have identified competing forces at Cape Darnley in East Antarctica that regulate the formation of Antarctic Bottom Water, an icy current that acts as a conveyor belt driving ocean circulation worldwide. The findings suggest that increased ice shelf melting or reduced sea ice could disrupt this system, affecting rainfall in Africa and temperatures in Europe[1][2][3].

"This very cold, salty water, called Antarctic Bottom Water, is formed by the freezing of the ocean surface in sea ice factories that we call polynyas," said Dr. David Gwyther of The University of Queensland, who led the research team. "This dense water sinks to the ocean floor where it flows northwards acting like a giant conveyor belt driving currents around the planet which influence the climate worldwide"[1][2][3].

items.title: US, EU sanction 70 shadow fleet vessels aiding Iran and Russia

featured_image.name: Shadow fleet — from smuggling to spying and sabotage

items.description:
The United States and European Union launched coordinated sanctions Wednesday targeting 70 vessels accused of helping Iran and Russia circumvent international oil export restrictions, marking a significant escalation in Western efforts to cut off revenue streams financing Tehran's military programs and Moscow's war in Ukraine.

The U.S. Treasury Department sanctioned 29 vessels and their management firms for transporting hundreds of millions of dollars worth of Iranian petroleum products through deceptive shipping practices, according to a Treasury statement[1][2]. On the same day, the European Union added 41 vessels to its blacklist, primarily targeting tankers moving Russian crude oil, along with nine individuals and entities linked to major Russian oil companies[3][4][5].

"As President Trump has said repeatedly, the United States will not allow Iran to have a nuclear weapon," Treasury Under Secretary for Terrorism and Financial Intelligence John K. Hurley said in the announcement[1][6]. "Treasury will continue to deprive the regime of the petroleum revenue it uses to fund its military and weapons programs."

items.title: EU agrees to €90B loan for Ukraine through 2027

featured_image.name: EU proposes using Russian assets, loans to fund $105bn package to Ukraine

items.description:
European Union leaders reached a deal early Friday to provide Ukraine with €90 billion in financial and military support for 2026-2027, but only after intense late-night negotiations forced a significant pivot from the bloc's original plan to use frozen Russian assets.

EU Council President António Costa announced the breakthrough on social media, declaring "We have a deal. Decision to provide 90 billion euros of support to Ukraine for 2026-27 approved. We committed, we delivered"[1][2]. The agreement came as Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy warned that without the first tranche of funding by spring, Ukraine would face a €45-59 billion shortfall and be unable to keep pace with Russia in drone production[3][4].

Rather than tapping the approximately €210 billion in frozen Russian assets held largely in Belgium—the EU's preferred "reparations loan" option—leaders ultimately agreed to raise joint debt backed by the bloc's budget[5][6][7]. The shift came after Belgian Prime Minister Bart De Wever maintained fierce opposition throughout the summit, fearing his country would be left exposed to Russian legal retaliation since most Russian assets sit at Brussels-based Euroclear[8][9][10].

items.title: Trump's inflation claims contradicted by new data

featured_image.name: Trump faces backlash on economy as inflation rises

items.description:
President Donald Trump's assertions that he has stopped inflation and rapidly brought down prices are meeting fresh skepticism following new government data released Thursday showing persistent cost pressures, even as some relief emerges at the gas pump.

The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported Thursday that consumer prices rose 2.7 percent in the 12 months ending in November, with food costs climbing 2.6 percent over the same period[1][2][3]. The figures directly contradict Trump's claim in his Wednesday evening address that "inflation has stopped"[4][5]. The meat, poultry, fish, and eggs index surged 4.7 percent over the past year, while nonalcoholic beverages jumped 4.3 percent[1][2].

The data release comes one day after Trump delivered a prime-time speech from the White House claiming his administration is "bringing our economy back from the brink of ruin" and insisting "prices are coming down tremendously"[6][7]. The president has made similar assertions throughout December, telling supporters in Pennsylvania that "we're bringing those prices down rapidly"[8][9].

items.title: EU leaders deadlock on frozen Russian assets for Ukraine

featured_image.name: Putin ally Viktor Orbán tells CNBC using frozen Russian assets is a ...

items.description:
European Union leaders convened in Brussels on December 18 for a marathon summit aimed at securing Ukraine's financial lifeline for 2026 and 2027, but remained sharply divided over whether to use approximately €210 billion in frozen Russian assets to fund the aid package[1][2][3].

The contentious debate pits Belgium, which holds most of the frozen funds at the Brussels-based clearinghouse Euroclear, against member states pushing for an unprecedented "reparations loan" that would leverage Russian central bank assets immobilized since Moscow's February 2022 invasion[1][2].

items.title: Senate confirms Trump picks, ending NLRB paralysis

featured_image.name: US Senate confirms Trump nominees for labor board paralyzed ...

items.description:
The U.S. Senate on Thursday voted 53-43 along party lines to confirm President Donald Trump's nominees to the National Labor Relations Board, ending nearly 11 months of paralysis at the agency charged with enforcing federal labor law[1][2][3].

The confirmations of Scott Mayer, chief labor lawyer at Boeing, and James Murphy, a retired career NLRB attorney, restore the three-member quorum needed for the board to decide cases[1][2][3]. The Senate also confirmed Crystal Carey, a partner at major labor law firm Morgan Lewis, as the agency's general counsel[1][2][3]. The vote was part of a larger package that confirmed 97 Trump nominees for posts throughout the federal government[4][2].

items.title: Food prices keep rising despite Trump's relief claims

featured_image.name: Trump now says bringing down grocery prices, as ... - ABC News

items.description:
President Donald Trump's assertion that he is "bringing those elevated prices down" came under immediate scrutiny Thursday as new federal data revealed food costs continue to rise, with beef prices hitting particularly steep increases.

Hours after Trump's Wednesday evening address to the nation, the Bureau of Labor Statistics released inflation data showing the food index rose 2.6% over the past year through November[1][2][3]. The report revealed particularly sharp increases for meat products, with the index for meat, poultry, fish and eggs surging 4.7% over the last 12 months[1][4][5].

items.title: Trump signs record $901B defense bill into law

featured_image.name: President Trump Delivers Oval Office Address To The Nation

items.description:
President Donald Trump signed the National Defense Authorization Act into law on December 18, authorizing $901 billion in military and national security programs for fiscal year 2026[1][2][3]. The legislation, which passed the Senate 77-20 and the House 312-112, represents an $8 billion increase over the administration's initial budget request and marks Congress's 65th consecutive year approving the annual defense policy bill[4][5][6].

The measure includes $400 million in military assistance for Ukraine in each of the next two fiscal years, totaling $800 million through the Ukraine Security Assistance Initiative[7][4][8]. According to The Atlantic Council, this represents a sharp decrease from the nearly $14 billion in Ukraine aid included in April 2024's supplemental legislation, reflecting reduced overall U.S. support during 2025[7].

items.title: Trump signs bill lifting Syria sanctions after Assad ouster

featured_image.name: Trump hosts Syria's al-Sharaa at White House as US extends sanctions relief

items.description:
President Donald Trump signed sweeping defense legislation on Thursday that permanently eliminates sanctions on Syria, marking a dramatic policy shift one year after former President Bashar Assad's ouster[1][2]. The move, embedded in the nearly $900 billion National Defense Authorization Act, passed the Senate 77-20 on Wednesday before heading to Trump's desk[3][4].

The repeal of the 2019 Caesar Syria Civilian Protection Act removes penalties that had targeted individuals and entities doing business with Assad's regime for war crimes during Syria's 14-year civil war[5][6]. Syrian Foreign Minister Asaad Al-Shaibani welcomed the Senate vote, calling it "a positive development that opens new horizons for cooperation and partnership between our country and the world"[7][8].

items.title: US approves record $11B Taiwan arms sale as China tensions rise

featured_image.name: China says U.S. will only 'harm itself' after Washington approves $11 billion arms sale to Taiwan

items.description:
The United States approved an $11.15 billion arms sale to Taiwan on Thursday, marking the largest weapons package for the island in history and intensifying diplomatic friction with Beijing at a moment when military communication channels between the two powers remain fragile[1][2][3]. The sale comes as experts warn that a dangerous imbalance is emerging between China's growing confidence and what they characterize as an increasingly defeatist American posture—a divergence that heightens the risk of strategic miscalculation.

China reacted strongly to the arms package, with Foreign Ministry spokesperson Guo Jiakun stating it "seriously undermines the One-China Principle" and warning that the United States "will ultimately harm itself"[1]. The transaction includes artillery systems, antitank missiles, and spare parts for helicopters, and arrives just two days after China's newest aircraft carrier, the Fujian, transited the Taiwan Strait—its first passage through the waterway since commissioning[4]. Beijing has conducted 40 aircraft sorties near Taiwan in the past 24 hours, with more than half crossing the strait's unofficial median line[4].

items.title: Cotton urges cyber director to counter foreign threats in open-source code

featured_image.name: How to Secure Open Source Software: The Dilemma of ...

items.description:
Senate Intelligence Committee Chairman Tom Cotton is pressing the White House's top cybersecurity official to address vulnerabilities stemming from Chinese and Russian contributions to open-source software used across U.S. government systems, citing recent incidents that exposed the risks of relying on code maintained by foreign adversaries.

In a letter sent Wednesday to National Cyber Director Sean Cairncross, the Arkansas Republican warned that "state-sponsored software developers and cyber espionage groups have started to exploit this communal environment, which assumes that contributors are benevolent, to insert malicious code into widely used open-source codebases"[1][2][3].

Cotton's concerns center on the federal government's heavy dependence on open-source software—free, publicly available code that relies on volunteer contributors for updates and security patches. While such software powers everything from defense systems to civilian agency operations, Cotton argued this trust-based model has become a national security liability[1][2].

items.title: Jared Isaacman sworn in as NASA's youngest administrator

featured_image.name: 41-year-old who just completed the first civilian spacewalk dropped out of high school to start his $7 billion business

items.description:
Jared Isaacman, the 42-year-old billionaire entrepreneur and commercial astronaut, was sworn in Thursday as NASA's 15th administrator, becoming the youngest person ever to lead the space agency[1][2][3]. His confirmation ends nearly a year of leadership uncertainty at NASA as the agency confronts severe budget cuts and prepares for its first crewed lunar mission in over five decades.

The U.S. Senate confirmed Isaacman in a 67-30 vote on Wednesday, following a tumultuous nomination process[4][5]. President Donald Trump first nominated Isaacman in December 2024, withdrew the nomination in May amid tensions with SpaceX CEO Elon Musk, then renominated him in November[6][7].

U.S. District Judge Timothy J. Kelly administered the oath of office during a ceremony at the Eisenhower Executive Office Building in Washington[1][8]. Isaacman replaces Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy, who had served as acting administrator since July[9][2].

items.title: Israel, Egypt finalize $35B gas deal under US pressure

featured_image.name: Leviathan partners ink $610m deal for new pipeline to boost gas exports to Egypt

items.description:
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced approval of a $35 billion natural gas export agreement with Egypt on Wednesday, marking the culmination of months of political pressure from the Trump administration to strengthen regional ties and advance broader Middle East peace efforts[1][2][3].

The deal, which Netanyahu called "the largest gas deal in Israel's history," will supply Egypt with 130 billion cubic meters of gas from Israel's Leviathan field through 2040[4][5][6]. The agreement involves US energy giant Chevron and Israeli partners NewMed Energy and Ratio Energies, and is expected to generate $18 billion in revenues for Israel's state coffers[4][7].

items.title: Instacart faces $60M settlement, FTC probe over pricing

featured_image.name: Instacart to Pay $60 Million to Settle FTC Consumer ...

items.description:
Instacart agreed to pay $60 million to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations of deceptive advertising while simultaneously facing a separate agency investigation into its artificial intelligence-driven pricing experiments, marking a dual regulatory challenge for the grocery delivery platform.

The FTC announced Thursday that the settlement resolves claims that Instacart misled consumers through false "free delivery" promises, inadequate disclosure of subscription terms, and a misleading satisfaction guarantee[1][2][3][4][5]. The separate investigation, revealed Wednesday, targets the company's Eversight pricing tool after a study found some shoppers were charged up to 23% more than others for identical items at the same stores[6][7][8].

items.title: Trump slashes science funding, targets climate research

featured_image.name: Trump administration moves to dismantle prominent US weather and climate research center

items.description:
The Trump administration announced plans this week to dismantle the National Center for Atmospheric Research in Colorado, the latest move in a year of unprecedented changes to U.S. science policy that has included historic funding cuts, a 43-day government shutdown, and the departure of hundreds of thousands of federal employees[1][2][3].

White House budget director Russell Vought announced Tuesday that the National Science Foundation will break up NCAR, calling the Boulder facility "one of the largest sources of climate alarmism in the country"[1][2]. The decision comes as part of broader efforts by President Donald Trump's administration to reshape the 80-year-old system of federal support for scientific research, with proposed cuts of nearly $18 billion to the National Institutes of Health and $5 billion to the NSF[4][5][6].

items.title: Researchers reveal faster sodium batteries and safer solid electrolytes

featured_image.name: Oxford scientists create solid battery material that works like liquid electrolyte

items.description:
Researchers at Oxford and Tokyo universities published separate studies on December 17 revealing advances in next-generation battery materials that could accelerate adoption of electric vehicles and renewable energy storage systems.

Tokyo University of Science scientists demonstrated that sodium-ion batteries can charge faster than conventional lithium-ion cells when using hard carbon electrodes[1][2][3][4]. Meanwhile, Oxford University researchers developed organic materials that maintain ionic conductivity when transitioning from liquid to solid states, addressing a key safety concern in battery design[5][6][7][8].

items.title: Hubble captures first asteroid collisions around nearby star

featured_image.name: Astronomers Catch Incredible First Direct Images Of Objects Colliding In Another Star System

items.description:
Astronomers have directly imaged catastrophic collisions between asteroid-like objects in a neighboring star system for the first time, solving a two-decade mystery about a vanishing "exoplanet" while providing a rare window into the violent early days of planetary formation. The findings, published today in Science, mark a historic milestone in observing how planets are built[1][2].

NASA's Hubble Space Telescope captured the aftermath of two massive smashups around Fomalhaut, one of the brightest stars in the night sky located 25 light-years from Earth in the constellation Piscis Austrinus[1][2][3]. The collisions involved planetesimals—rocky building blocks of planets—each about 37 miles across, creating enormous dust clouds that initially masqueraded as planets[2][4].

"This is certainly the first time I've ever seen a point of light appear out of nowhere in an exoplanetary system," said Paul Kalas, principal investigator at the University of California, Berkeley[2][5]. "It's absent in all of our previous Hubble images, which means that we just witnessed a violent collision between two massive objects and a huge debris cloud unlike anything in our own solar system today."

items.title: Blue Origin delays historic flight with first wheelchair user to space

featured_image.name: Blue Origin launch to mark first-ever wheelchair user in space

items.description:
Blue Origin delayed its planned Thursday launch that would have sent the first wheelchair user into space, after high winds and technical issues forced the company to postpone the milestone mission[1][2]. The NS-37 flight, scheduled to lift off at 11:00 a.m. ET from the company's Launch Site One in West Texas, was scrubbed after the launch team observed an unspecified issue during pre-flight checks[2][3].

Michaela "Michi" Benthaus, an aerospace and mechatronics engineer at the European Space Agency, was set to make history as the first person using a wheelchair to reach the edge of space[4][5]. The German engineer has used a wheelchair since suffering a spinal cord injury in a 2018 mountain biking accident[4][6]. "This feels like an important step since space travel for people with disabilities is still in its very early days," Benthaus said in a LinkedIn post[7]. "I'm so thankful and hope it inspires a change in mindset across the space industry, creating more opportunities for people like me."

items.title: House Democrats release 68 photos from Epstein estate

featured_image.name: US Congress releases Epstein estate photos featuring Trump, Clinton

items.description:
House Democrats on the Oversight Committee released 68 photographs from Jeffrey Epstein's estate Thursday, unveiling disturbing images one day before the Justice Department faces a statutory deadline to disclose a much larger trove of documents related to the convicted sex offender[1][2][3].

The photos, selected from a cache of 95,000 images obtained from Epstein's estate, include a woman's foot inscribed with a line from the novel "Lolita," a Ukrainian woman's passport, and a screenshot of text messages about an 18-year-old from Russia[4][1][5]. The release also features photos of billionaire Bill Gates with a woman whose face was redacted, and philosopher Noam Chomsky on a plane with Epstein[1][2][3].

"As we approach the deadline for the Epstein Files Transparency Act, these new images raise more questions about what exactly the Department of Justice has in its possession," said Representative Robert Garcia of California, the ranking Democrat on the committee[2]. "We must end this White House cover-up, and the DOJ must release the Epstein files now."
